Award.AwardTitle: Selenium recovery from wastewater based on exclusively extracellular selenium nanoparticles production

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Selenium (Se) is critical element to the US economy and national security. It is also a contaminant in wastewater that must be removed to meet strict discharge limits to the environment. Bacteria have been used previously to remove Se from wastewater by converting dissolved Se to Se nanoparticles that can be separated from the water. However, this process is not efficient for Se recovery because the Se nanoparticles are typically inside the microbial cells and thus difficult to recover. The goal of this project is to enable both Se removal and recovery from wastewater using novel biocathode reactors. In these systems, specific bacteria grow on electrodes and produce Se nanoparticles outside microbial cells for efficient Se recovery. Successful completion of this research will improve our understanding of the mechanisms of Se nanoparticle production in biocathode reactors. Additional benefits to the environment and society result from improving Se recovery from wastewater. The potential economic benefits of this process are significant, as Se recovery just from coal-fired power plant waste streams alone could meet all the US demand for this element. Broader impacts to society will result from an education and outreach plan focused on the role that bacteria play in the process. This will improve the scientific literacy of the Nation by correcting misperceptions that all bacteria are human pathogens.

The goal of this project is to develop a novel biocathode reactor system to recover selenium (Se) from wastewater at coal-fired power plants and other Se-rich waste streams. This research is driven by new Environmental Protection Agency regulations greatly reducing the Se effluent limit from coal-fired power plant wastewater. Additionally, increased demand for Se in many different products and industries makes recovery and re-use a more sustainable means of meeting this increased demand. Microbial Se reactors exploit the microbial conversion of dissolved selenate to elemental Se nanoparticles. Previous research on Se bioreactors has not been able to demonstrate efficient recovery of Se because the elemental Se nanoparticles are produced intracellularly and thereby difficult to separate. Preliminary experiments in our laboratory using novel biocathode reactors have demonstrated the ability of specially enriched mixed cultures to produce extracellular Se nanoparticles on the biocathode regardless of inoculum. The first objective of this project is to determine the mechanisms of extracellular Se nanoparticle production on the biocathode. The effect of potential interferences like nitrate and sulfate that are commonly present in Se-laden wastewater will also be investigated. Techniques to prevent the negative effects of nitrate and sulfate on selenate reduction will be developed through integrated mathematical modeling with experiments on microbial community structure, function, and kinetics. Successful completion of this research has potential to be expanded for the recovery of other minerals of US national interests such as Cr, Pd, Sb, and U. Broader educational impacts to society result from an education and outreach plan focused on the production of an educational video of beneficial versus harmful bacteria, outreach efforts to attract students from underrepresented groups in STEM research and education, and a competition-based design project to accelerate knowledge transfer to engineers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to recover selenium (Se) from wastewater such as coal-fired power plant wastewater. On the one hand, Se is a water contaminant regulated by the U.S. environmental protection agency. On the other hand, Se is one of the critical elements for low carbon energy technologies and one of the high-risk elements vulnerable to supply and other restrictions. A bioelectrochemical reactor with a biocathode was used to achieve this goal by converting dissolved Se including selenate and selenite to elemental Se nanoparticles. No matter mixed or pure microbial cultures were used to inoculate the biocathode, the bioelectrochemical reactor produced significantly more extracellular Se nanoparticles compared to the biofilm reactor control. The extracellular Se nanoparticles are more convenient to recover than the intracellular Se nanoparticles since there is no need to breakdown the microbial cells. This project advances knowledge on extracellular Se nanoparticles production on the biocathode. It was found that bacteria preferred to produce extracellular Se nanoparticles on the biocathode and intracellular Se nanoparticles in the biofilm reactor control. To produce Se nanoparticles, electrons were needed to reduce selenate or selenite via redox reactions. On the biocathode, electrons were directly available on the microbial cells’ outer surfaces. This direct availability made the energy costs low for microbial cells to produce extracellular Se nanoparticles.

Nitrate and sulfate are commonly coexisting chemicals with selenate and selenite in wastewater. They can affect the production and recovery of Se nanoparticles. The sulfate concentrations are usually very high in wastewater, e.g., thousands mg S/L. This is inhibitory to selenate reduction. The inhibitory effects were much higher in the biofilm reactor control than in the bioelectrochemical reactor. Selenide production was commonly neglected in previous selenium removal studies. It was found that this neglection could have significantly overestimated the removal of selenium when the sulfate concentration was very high. It was further found that the sulfate reduction and selenide production were more than 10 times higher in the biofilm reactor control than in the bioelectrochemical reactor. The effects of nitrate depended on its concentration. When the ratio of nitrate-N: selenate-Se was less than 1:1, nitrate promoted the conversion of selenate to Se nanoparticles due to inducing selenate reductases. When the ratio was higher than 1.5:1, nitrate inhibited the conversion of selenate due to due to competition for limited common resources such as electrons.

These research findings have expanded knowledge in bioelectrochemistry, and have been published in four journal articles. Another two journal manuscripts are under review or preparation. In addition to the research outcomes, this project has broader impacts. It produced an educational video as a platform to address a public misperception of Bacteria = Pathogens. It also produced a Se-recovery prototype as a platform for engaging students from underrepresented groups. This project graduated one Ph.D. student from Africa. This student received a scholarship from the Air and Waste Management Association (AWMA) and a Danfoss Research Fellowship. One minority undergraduate student participated in research in this project for more than one year and received the Lisa Scott Undergraduate Research Award from Florida State University.  More undergraduate and high school students participated in research for less than one year through the Young Scholar Program and the Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program at Florida State University, and internship at Florida A&M University. This platform was also used for K-12 education by being exhibited at the Second Annual Biotechnology Expo in the Challenger Learning Center, Tallahassee, Florida.

Modified by: Youneng Tang
